name: De Bruijn–Newman constant
summary: The De Bruijn–Newman constant (\(\Lambda \)) is a mathematical constant related to the zeros of a specific function \(H(\lambda ,z)\), which is connected to the Riemann zeta function. It defines the threshold for when all zeros of the function \(H\) are real. A key implication is that the Riemann hypothesis—a major unsolved problem in mathematics—is equivalent to the statement that \(\Lambda \le 0\).
